title: 107_hr1687
content: The "Poverty Trap Study Act of 2001" acknowledges that low-income individuals face high effective marginal tax rates, which can exceed 100 percent, discouraging them from working more, getting raises, or engaging in economic activities. This Act establishes a National Commission on Marginal Tax Rates for the Working Poor. The National Commission on Marginal Tax Rates for the Working Poor is established to determine total effective marginal tax rates for individuals earning between $7,000 and $30,000 per year in at least 5 states. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed by various congressional leaders. The National Commission on Marginal Tax Rates for the Working Poor consists of 12 members appointed by congressional leaders. The Commission's members include appointees from the Senate Majority Leader, Senate Minority Leader, and the President. The Chairman is elected at the first meeting, and appointments are for the life of the Commission. Meetings are called by the Chairman or majority members, with a quorum of 7 members required. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed by congressional leaders. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members receive no additional pay but are entitled to travel expenses and per diem. The Chairman appoints an executive director who is paid at the rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. Staff appointments require Commission approval. The executive director of the Commission may appoint staff without regard to civil service laws, and may procure temporary services. The Administrator of General Services will provide office space for the Commission's headquarters. The Commission's headquarters will include all necessary equipment for its functioning. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, request studies from the GAO, and detail federal employees to assist in its duties. The Commission may request technical assistance from Federal agencies, use the United States mails, obtain information directly from agencies, and request administrative support services to carry out its duties. The Commission shall provide information to the Commission, receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services, and be considered a committee of Congress for printing costs. A report with findings and recommendations must be submitted to Congress within a year, and the Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. The Commission is not subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Not more than $900,000 is authorized for appropriations for this section.
